elements.2211.03068_f339f0bc61fb0e559f9ef4b2e4947: Intermediate languages are used in compilers
elements.2211.03068_fd4f668fbcca79ed47f971299fb0f: to translate the source code into a form that is easy to optimize and increase portability
elements.2211.03068_0c0c78e1e11c18f8f444481acd83e: The term intermediate language also refers to the intermediate language used by the compilers of high level languages that does not produce any machine code, such as Java and C
elements.2211.03068_09627a70800fff9e75d681757a384: An example of adding two numbers in the intermediate language CIL (Common Intermediate Language) used in implementing C
elements.2211.03068_c12dfc1453311e9fe6ae858c4d823: CIL is a stack based language, i.e: the data is pushed on the stack instead of pulling from the registers
elements.2211.03068_218e4e52a80fcf4821a0f4ea97fdd: That is one of the reasons why, in the example above, one simple add statement is translated into four stack-based statements
elements.2211.03068_784d1b37544f507575dce8fc2622e: The same add statement can be translated into the
elements.2211.03068_73af7acd55dd613b298e0cf819f12: is an intermediate language used by most of the compilers
elements.2211.03068_996b445866a551b83bf12c77894e3: The two popular open source compilers GCC
elements.2211.03068_69e49d8e8890ba2d75284b2ff75ec: as part of there intermediate languages.
elements.2211.03068_cd1ecf092072e9474ee784664a423: Detecting whether a given program is a malware (virus) is an undecidable problem
elements.2211.03068_ab70b7a1f783c3dbccd02466633f4: Antimalware software detection techniques are limited by this theoretical result
elements.2211.03068_fa53be4b6a5b3c6a5b5b4d18514f7: Malware writers exploit this limitation to avoid detection
elements.2211.03068_50d21fde3641f05bbdc3805cc3da8: In the early days the malware writers were hobbyists but now the professionals have become part of this group because of the financial gains
elements.2211.03068_54396517ef695c4c9cfb8b4bbcb65: One of the basic techniques used by a malware writer is obfuscation
elements.2211.03068_cf4b645a977077c8105e55be33bfa: Such a technique obscure a code to make it difficult to understand, analyze and detect malwares embedded in the code
elements.2211.03068_eed2fa66ac05f86e6ef117bdf526c: Initial obfuscators were simple and were detected by signature-based detectors
elements.2211.03068_1e1b5e5543e426d772e48a3ad107b: These signature-based detectors work on simple signatures such as byte sequences, instruction sequences and string signatures (pattern of a malware that uniquely identifies it)
elements.2211.03068_4c26d41161bcaeb49db1a6e6432c2: They lack information about the semantics or behavior of the malicious program
elements.2211.03068_d1f6ee5570d29be5bc8c854d9567b: To counter these detectors the obfuscation techniques evolved
elements.2211.03068_c450b86095fb9eb75408da8233690: Some of the mutations used in polymorphic and metamorphic
elements.2211.03068_824f1fabedd95fb419ce97192c399: By changing the ordering of instructions with commutative or associative operators, the structure of the instructions can be changed
elements.2211.03068_082d30b242736e31a09139a781c34: This reordering does not change the behavior of the program
elements.2211.03068_c4de8d963072f8b0e2cb5489a625d: Because of the two reordered instructions the original and the changed machine codes have different signatures
elements.2211.03068_9d1f9f78af422404ec9b9f2955731: Other instructions can also be reordered if no dependency exists between the instructions.
elements.2211.03068_33565ae3873e61a5b304939180306: Dead code is a code that either does not execute or has no effect on the results of a program
elements.2211.03068_2809e2325f79af52d839ff5b70f2d: Following is an example of dead code insertion:
elements.2211.03068_1a22fded1a8485e9248c1f43d2430: To avoid detection registers are reassigned in a fragment of a binary code
elements.2211.03068_880c4820ae5ed595de5d1c5582764: This changes the byte sequence (signature) of the machine code
elements.2211.03068_c57f656cbd91554bb63aaeaf59b86: A signature-based detector will not be able to match the signature if it is searching for a specific register
elements.2211.03068_edcae8899f853ccdd84103f4806de: An example of register renaming is given below (register
elements.2211.03068_44b8383aa870017be5a6219aa8312: To change the control flow of a program the order of instructions is changed in the binary image of the program, keeping the order of execution the same by using jump instructions.
elements.2211.03068_01b4853de25e3e7f922966435497f: to obscure the flow of control in a program
elements.2211.03068_e9cee93102d44cd6e216a1a45201b: The target of all or some of the unconditional branches in a program is replaced by the address of a branch function
elements.2211.03068_b5f54f34bea1d62351ba6bc1013f8: The branch function makes sure the branch is correctly transferred to the right target for each branch.
elements.2211.03068_fe4f2acd2cdfe920c454e828c9865: Because of the financial gains attached with the malware industry, malware writers are always targeting new technologies
elements.2211.03068_e858708bf298956a7ea31337e7647: To improve the detection of malwares, especially metamorphic malwares, we need to develop new methods and techniques to analyze behavior of a program, to make a better detection decision with few false positives.
elements.2211.03068_110807dd8f120b34879740e011e67: Why an Intermediate Language for Malware Analysis
elements.2211.03068_6d32b9ae1442cf144ee642d1adb84: Here we are going to list some of the reasons why we need to transform a program in an assembly language to an intermediate language for malware analysis:
elements.2211.03068_99367cf002cf041d1445fefad588a: There are hundreds of different instructions in any assembly language
elements.2211.03068_5d757e534a3039967d5d9382ce46f: For example the number of instructions in the two most popular ISAs (Instruction Set Architectures) are: Intel x86-64 = 800+
elements.2211.03068_2b58110c2d294d215db36ec51b12a: We need to reduce the number of these instructions considerably to optimize the static analysis of any such assembly program.
elements.2211.03068_f45ddd6e7af17faad2846b63095d3: Not only the different instructions are big in numbers but they are also big in complexity, such as Intel x86-64 instruction's
elements.2211.03068_e194c99ce0a8eff7b78828519669e: moves data from the memory to the cache
elements.2211.03068_c4f048c782f9639430b308804cf4f: Is this action important, if we are performing a static analysis for detecting malwares? Our answer is 'NO'
elements.2211.03068_466346dbd39bec8e716537174b346: There are other such instructions that are not required for malware analysis
elements.2211.03068_1cacee6eab3a4fa442934b68f1967: So our intermediate language hide/ignore these instructions and make the language transparent to the static analysis
elements.2211.03068_c3920c8abae594f633484aaa7a549: copy a double word or a quad word respectively, from the source operand to the destination operand
elements.2211.03068_04d35163c9a9c8bcb9349958d7728: Here we have to ask a question do we need to take into account the size of the word being copied in our static analysis? If the answer is 'NO', then in our intermediate language we can replace these kind of instructions with a much simpler
elements.2211.03068_1c2c462a5100e27dd3c302fbca277: Using such techniques an intermediate language allows us to use simple instructions to make our static analysis much simpler.
elements.2211.03068_0c5db4fa3f6c776325186e427f178: We want a common intermediate language that can be used with different platforms, such as Intel x86-64 and ARM
elements.2211.03068_6c8218fcd54aece86d146628f94dc: So we do not have to perform separate static analysis for each platform
elements.2211.03068_e1e8e948577c5d386139928ce80ed: The intermediate language could be used for any of the above mentioned or other such platforms.
elements.2211.03068_b16ba56662917d04d5ed8c66f5586: Assembly instructions can have multiple hidden side effects, such as effecting the flags etc, that can substantially increase the efforts required for the static analysis
elements.2211.03068_ba34b6597f4f40525b067092c3a24: In this case there are three options that an intermediate language can use to make the static analysis easier: Either remove all the side effects, or have only one side effect, or explicitly define side effect(s) in the instruction
elements.2211.03068_8a4d6ef7fba3136b5021ce7d79c4c: Because our focus is mainly on malware analysis, out of these three, in our opinion the first option is the best option
elements.2211.03068_9b88cd7dbd6e4b454d7e44c14766c: We will use this option in our intermediate language, and the instructions used in our language that we call MAIL (Malware Analysis Intermediate Language) will not have any side effects.
elements.2211.03068_c199fa445c56c9488dea5b1c9d6c6: Unknown branch addresses in an assembly makes it difficult to build a correct CFG
elements.2211.03068_c5c6d6c5c7ca9161209d3878dd1cc: This problem will be taken care of by the MAIL
elements.2211.03068_f818b19c8e304cecb4d3aecce6cf1: For example, for indirect jumps and calls (branches whose target is unknown or cannot be determined by static analysis) only a change in the source code can change them, so it is safe to ignore these branches for malware analysis where the change is only carried out in the machine code
elements.2211.03068_1cbeab5311b778835806906bf15a8: We explain this using an example from one of the PARSEC
elements.2211.03068_c781f95ca5286fa766e8999407fa2: The following example shows the function
elements.2211.03068_863c13d8e8253a0bebcc3e3f0e509: from one of the benchmarks in the PARSEC benchmark suite
elements.2211.03068_51e6467130d725e714f308b5e9376: This function initializes a static condition variable of a thread
elements.2211.03068_320e5afb94d662eda0ca3abbb8a65: statement to jump to an appropriate exception generated by a
elements.2211.03068_533d2e83f1565f2c0815ed56095cc: This function initializes the condition variable of a thread and returns zero if successful otherwise returns an error number
elements.2211.03068_b0351f1db10902b50928677924e8a: function can only be determined at runtime and so the value of
elements.2211.03068_55675787a53186f66b7fad3233d66: Dynamic analysis can be used to determine the value of
elements.2211.03068_45f5fe8f024d93fb62b312ba2afc3: , but it is possible that such an analysis may not be able to reach (in one of the runs) one of the executable paths (the
elements.2211.03068_73cb3a59e8da07323811937fc51c0: statement) in the case of the
elements.2211.03068_186b73cce767b1773fb46204d03a8: being always zero and changes only in rare cases
elements.2211.03068_5272fb4e6f1ee3f4782d7bd70144c: These rare cases may not get executed or execute only after running the program for a very long time, that may render the analysis impractical
elements.2211.03068_879a55d0d2543748310da0f7e5be9: A malware writer can exploit this weakness and inject the malware code by changing the target address of any of the branches inside the
elements.2211.03068_057553a76953d7c129424ae103eda: statement to his/her own malicious code
elements.2211.03068_e9e055a08a69a36aa9867bec551a2: In such a case the dynamic analysis will not be able to detect this malicious behavior
elements.2211.03068_9d0d816ccf628df6bda762fc038c4: That is where static (binary) analysis can help by building a CFG that covers all the available execution paths, in this case the
elements.2211.03068_b36b79e62aba04d7266d3877c971b: This CFG may not be correct, because by looking at the disassembled (the assembly) code above we can see it generates an unknown branch target address
elements.2211.03068_5f2a7ababa1eb1ec8d91acd4ae9bc: This address cannot be computed using static analysis
elements.2211.03068_525a2bb554b8498470fdb95c94791: Is it safe to ignore this branch target address while building the CFG for malware analysis? It is not possible for a malware writer to use this particular instruction as it is for malicious code
elements.2211.03068_35e24a6022444381765185d8fd0b8: He/she will have to change this instruction to make it easy to use, such as the register
elements.2211.03068_2025aba84ce4cc9321f76fce7bded: can be loaded with an address of a malicious code before the
elements.2211.03068_3397f8fc84d4bf59185f0b8cb6920: instruction, which is trivial to detect because in this case the branch target address will become known
elements.2211.03068_6373a300a95df719360e1d327dede: The language MAIL is specifically designed for malware analysis, so we create a new construct/keyword
elements.2211.03068_74f3f2660886929dcdcd3b647a182: that takes care of these branches
elements.2211.03068_796b00f2517c2dcfe640ba1711929: This construct will be helpful not only in static but also in dynamic analysis of the malwares.
elements.2211.03068_88e3a400a1c72ce2c05265e4d324e: A language such as MAIL can be easily translated into a string, a tree or a graph and hence can be optimized for various analysis that are required for malware analysis and detection, such as pattern matching and data mining
elements.2211.03068_8e2a8a854e5f4c916ad1381b179c1: ) in the MAIL language for annotating MAIL statements that can be used for pattern matching.
elements.2211.03068_500ce86ef2fcaf3939b25bc177e62: To reduce the number of different instructions for static analysis, functionally equivalent assembly instructions can be grouped together in one intermediate language instruction, such as:
elements.2211.03068_d31a3d18207fad5cfa2ae0e19aa6d: In the following Sections we introduce the new language called MAIL (Malware Analysis Intermediate Language) for malware analysis and detection
elements.2211.03068_40336c309f2787a742e40a750ccfc: we describe its detail design and how a binary program is translated to MAIL
elements.2211.03068_3cf820da8c9543179db02d4915b73: We also cover the CFG (Control Flow Graph) construction and annotation and how graph and pattern matching techniques are used to detect metamorphic malwares
elements.2211.03068_14e31fa4074768e78d32095e8d3b6: We carried out an empirical study in Section
elements.2211.03068_77d05c79495c0c524ae6f6581e675: to test the use of MAIL in a tool
elements.2211.03068_035acedd23cff127e5dbd04c410fe: Using the MAIL language the tool was able to fully automate the process of malware analysis and detection and achieved 100
elements.2211.03068_87f244d5a9c43de177639d0e94b69: In the previous Section we provided motivations for a new language for malware analysis and detection
elements.2211.03068_7f65d46a844ca9ce0919bb2b72157: This Section, introduces and provides the design of, this new language called MAIL
elements.2211.03068_382b774a37504a1aafffe39a73860: The language MAIL is based on binary analysis to optimize malware detection, so before explaining it's design we first give some background on binary analysis for malware detection.
elements.2211.03068_3df49fa3948a4bd6404b1a7db5888: Almost all the malwares use binaries (instructions that a computer can interpret and execute) to infiltrate a computer system, which can be a desktop, a server, a laptop, a kiosk or a mobile device
elements.2211.03068_04a5d740ed4d8d280931582760012: Binary analysis is the process of automatically analysing the structure and behavior of a binary program
elements.2211.03068_71f0527caab5aec064d5ecd9f2b55: There are various purposes of this analysis and some of them are: optimization, verification, profiling, performance tuning and computer security
elements.2211.03068_f97d569bc8db6add6c0f85361186e: We further explain how binary analysis can help us understand a program and detect malwares in the program, by using a simple binary program (a function called
elements.2211.03068_f1048caa3c4d132478c9fb3632aa0: ) that is part of the class
elements.2211.03068_b0cdf1375b295935dc35dac8c960b: This function performs a merge sort on an array of integers
elements.2211.03068_db626fd0bfd906edcacea745215a3: It's binary analysis (performed using an in-house developed tool) information is listed below and explained in the following paragraphs:
elements.2211.03068_c850af6d01e012efe584234b90e59: The listing shown above is divided into two columns numbered I and II separated by a colon (:)
elements.2211.03068_e4c42a7ae6b7f65db4ad901059973: There are total 104 assembly instructions in this function
elements.2211.03068_8356afdd958a1ae7b2bf82ff54def: The first column lists the first 52 instructions and the second column lists the rest of the 52 instructions
elements.2211.03068_8ebf8f1e5f610d9d7a26a91942787: This function is part of a binary program (in ELF x86-64 file) that is first disassembled and then binary analysis is performed on the disassembled program for building CFGs of each function in this program
elements.2211.03068_a8e0b438470bf82db7a906e749f81: In the listing above each instruction is assigned a block number and an address
elements.2211.03068_d7017427c33f9221400938c805f15: Columns I and II are further divided into five columns: Column 1 is the block number, column 2 is the address, column 3 is the machine code, column 4 and 5 are the assembly instructions in Intel syntax
elements.2211.03068_50ae1be84dbf37499bf504e886ed6: The total number of blocks in this function are 12
elements.2211.03068_bb6aae164f2ad238f0a9a72e7df97: Each block contains different number of instructions
elements.2211.03068_7d9965940b4681c9eeffc8fa7fad4: For example block number 4 has only 1 instruction whereas block number 5 has 30 instructions
elements.2211.03068_77119754a281e99804c28a9fd5dfe: A block is a basic block
elements.2211.03068_8bc8f6f3c7302327fddbfdf71dcd6: that has the following properties: (1) It has only one entry but can have more than one exit points. (2) An instruction with a branch to another block in the same function ends the block. (3) If an instruction is a target of another branch within the same function then that instruction starts a new block
elements.2211.03068_88d559e5f9f02499f7a3e01c6da51: If an instruction branches to another block in the function listed above, the target instruction's block number is listed at the end enclosed in brackets
elements.2211.03068_f66e8487cf0d323d6cfcea5fe1160: For example the last instruction in block 1 ends with (6), because this instruction is branching to the address 401158 and the instruction at this address belongs to (is the first instruction of) block 6
elements.2211.03068_2ad34882fdb95a3faadf46eb4ab9d: Based on the analysis information listed above we build a CFG of this function that is shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_2ac247bca782df7257861839c0286: We are going to compare this CFG with the source code of this function in C++ which is shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_129003ab43e2f6226e2d2b19af0d1: The source code was not made available to our binary analysis tool, and the CFG that is build by this tool is only based on the information available in the binary program
elements.2211.03068_25c32737dd817da7ae8a730dcf99d: Now we want to see how much this analysis helps us to get information about the function for malware detection
elements.2211.03068_4a8f53ef6a10d46edb9b7a50f1f57: This function has been instrumented, i.e: additional code has been added to this function
elements.2211.03068_5e0bc0fa15d8257e375d0f6380359: There are three instructions at the end (number 101, 102 and 103) in Listing 1.1 that has been added to this function
elements.2211.03068_08a04abc189787b9dd82ca7ff754c: The first of these instructions INC
elements.2211.03068_44e11851c2084e1dd252769e0c48a: A increment a 32 bit counter CTR
elements.2211.03068_3e08761610aa15b9e6d85c68488cc: A jumps over the counter storage space to address 4011e4 which contains the RET instruction
elements.2211.03068_ff9e99893f9f9edee8f34ccc82645: The counter counts the number of times this function is called
elements.2211.03068_f1c918d19d4950d763ae4d9224ed5: This kind of instrumentation is done for profiling a program for further optimizations
elements.2211.03068_04b1521e836c63b43337b02b5bb6d: The CFG starts at block 0 and ends at block 12
elements.2211.03068_e767aafe3e1bd187f80e4da0b7304: This indicates a possibility of a loop
elements.2211.03068_d5af25c4d809b07b9a347170a4565: If we look at the CFG there is a loop that starts at block 1 and ends at block 11
elements.2211.03068_cda70b467878d53bafcb7093b337a: The blocks that belong to this loop are in red, green and blue colors
elements.2211.03068_6bde0dee076b2f090cfaebabb7ad2: This outer loop has two inner loops that are colored green and blue
elements.2211.03068_2c022a82641b14592189a4957565a: The source code of the function
elements.2211.03068_cd7392abebd5b6a159541ab1977bd: has exactly one outer loop and the outer loop has exactly two inner loops.
elements.2211.03068_34ef8921ecd540bafb5d67a750c83: A malware writer can change (just the machine code) the last instruction of block 11 in Listing 1.1:
elements.2211.03068_b2a702a6d6a46b9160f50da9711ac: This will make the outer loop an infinite loop and when the function
elements.2211.03068_ec4b7781cbf82903e6d7c87e8eeb6: is called the program will never return
elements.2211.03068_f12c8e28109f43a8b4b8de837125b: The malware writer in this case has added an unconditional back jump, which in general is a legal jump
elements.2211.03068_60a9b759bd5cd6f6c475b5b2e3043: Similarly other back jumps (last instructions of blocks 6 and 9) can also be changed by a malware writer to make more infinite loops
elements.2211.03068_be783909b06285d54d1b84cf0addc: So a signature based malware detection tool will not be able to detect such kind of malwares
elements.2211.03068_ca188db239118cb1b4e369fc66f33: Without the behavioral information, obtained either statically or dynamically, about a binary program a manual detection with a debugger is required to detect such malwares
elements.2211.03068_e3df2118b52ed30529a9d28318285: This manual labor is very time consuming and financially can become very expensive
elements.2211.03068_bd513bf946eb5cb7b69ee0ba1fe1e: To automate this process, a further binary analysis on the CFG will be able to detect this infinite loop as follows: We have already identified all the identifiable (more on this latter) loops in the function
elements.2211.03068_97c35e3e8539055ad060c4e9571aa: We will further analyse all the blocks that contain a back jump
elements.2211.03068_2321a4b5ed3f4ec8700b46dd0108e: In this case analysing block 11, we see that the TEST instruction is followed by an unconditional jump instruction (added by the malware writer), which indicates an illegal infinite loop and hence a malware
elements.2211.03068_2b5b97d38dbc00924435f1e16b7aa: In the case where a malware writer also replaces all the other four instructions with some other instructions, we will have to find the unconditional jump instruction to block 1 in block 11 (starting and ending blocks of the loop) to detect the malware, which in the presence of the CFG is trivial
elements.2211.03068_54299569e04dfd26c7d15fbbd36f2: What if this unconditional jump instruction is a legal instruction, i.e: it has not been added by a malware writer and is part of the program? For example event-based programs contain one or more infinite loops
elements.2211.03068_816ce98c4bdec3d6c8faf9b759018: In this case we may need to build specific control flow patterns and compare them with the previous control flow patterns of malwares of such kind
elements.2211.03068_280b13f110c6615a173aaaff77af1: Other malicious changes, such as the following register renaming and control flow change, in block 2 in Listing 1.1, cannot be detected by a signature based malware detector:
elements.2211.03068_088ce5ebcc289d7035da9473e93f8: In order to detect such anomaly based malwares automatically, we need control flow information as provided by the binary analysis presented in this Section
elements.2211.03068_5c7c471de6cd25b3346c12b18cd48: Another technique used by malware writers to deceive signature based detectors is to use instructions other than JMP and CALL to change the control flow of a program
elements.2211.03068_e4a1b44fb77f006667ae48bbc01fb: We show this by replacing the last instruction with two instructions in block 7 in Listing 1.1 as follows:
elements.2211.03068_2f024174f463b6d9dbfa9d7488f52: This change in Listing 1.1 is not finished here
elements.2211.03068_c94693e61da120318a464e166a8f1: For the code to work correctly the addresses following these instructions and all the effected jump target addresses needs to be updated
elements.2211.03068_c4f512d2713410ecae34ed8e4a622: A malware writer may or may not update them depending on the complexity of the malware
elements.2211.03068_f2a344adf20a97605a1a4e46d1e31: A tool could be used by the malware writer that can automate updating these addresses
elements.2211.03068_32459725b96d4d9978e4a754890da: A further binary analysis on the above instructions reveals that the last value pushed on the stack before the RET statement is 4011e5, so the RET instruction will move the value 4011e5 to the RIP register, the instruction pointer
elements.2211.03068_473d9358f77f98b0022cf3c61bbaa: Next time the instruction at address 4011e5 (malicious code) will be executed
elements.2211.03068_ff8b9d92406d5771644d0c0286398: The added instruction at address 40117e indicates the end of a function
elements.2211.03068_4e1c89c7e2b5648022c843fffb7d6: Sometimes the binary provides information about the start and end of all the functions in a program
elements.2211.03068_a79710e5891f07324b67b08217246: But if this information is not available it is difficult to find the exact start and end of some of the functions, e.g: the addition of the two instructions shown above in the function in Listing 1.1 divides the function into two functions and makes it difficult to find the original function
elements.2211.03068_f88feb0715e2a3e9332dc1d0e05db: For malware detection, we may only need to find where the control is flowing (i.e: just the behavior and not the function boundaries) and then compare this behavior with the previous samples of malwares available to detect such malwares.
elements.2211.03068_edec7ca3f602a06df96389df8280a: In the above paragraphs we have shown using an elaborate example, how trivial changes in the binary can make the malware analysis and detection intricate, difficult and expensive
elements.2211.03068_1fc69df5d786a17cd49df6b054a48: But with suitable tools and appropriate binary analysis it is possible to analyse and detect such malwares automatically
elements.2211.03068_cfab059ec7cf780acaa024d4429f9: (a)) from the disassembled instructions of the function in Listing 1.1 for malware analysis and detection
elements.2211.03068_beb8b2c21cc53acf4285e23a73024: In the next Section we describe the design of the intermediate language MAIL that automates and optimizes this step.
elements.2211.03068_7d204e1978b27e855381713d144df: We believe a good language must start small and simple, and must give opportunities to the language developers to grow (extend) the language with the users
elements.2211.03068_4d2c896680eaa218e65ea03a3a7a6: Therefore MAIL is designed as a small and simple, and an extensible language
elements.2211.03068_ee3f986bb57f4c1f373b270dabd45: In this and next Sections we describe how MAIL is designed in detail
elements.2211.03068_469b29a3c3a78c6a99dfbfc19f4d1: The basic purpose of the language MAIL is to represent structural and behavioral information of an assembly program for malware analysis and detection
elements.2211.03068_93332c0b7c9fab06c2d12e1fdeead: MAIL will also make the program more readable and understandable by a human malware analyst
elements.2211.03068_d3ec21e27ad6d6ce1d36246bb1356: An assembly program can comprise of the following type of instructions
elements.2211.03068_56c5fefcb120e021d20ec9d01bd62: We use Intel x86-64 assembly instructions
elements.2211.03068_486c5199de6b77ad190f9fbed8fc7: : These instructions include instructions that can change the control flow of the program, such as JMP, CALL, RET, CMP, CMPS, CMPPS, PCMPEQW, REP and LOOP instructions.
elements.2211.03068_3624f6c78d30c1a63c2412018f880: : These instructions perform arithmetic operations, such as ADD, SUB, MUL, DIV, FSIN, FCOS, PADDW, PSUBW, ADDPS, ADDPD, PMULLD, PAVGW, DPPD, SHR and SHL.
elements.2211.03068_67bd20ebb65cfc3b826f4b5489b64: : These include instructions that perform logical operations, such as AND, OR and NOT.
elements.2211.03068_058256b917a11ed469d8bccb06521: : These instructions involve data moving instructions, such as MOV, CMOV, XCHG, PUSH, POP, LODS, STOS, MOVS, MOVAPS, MOVAPD, IN, OUT, INS, OUTS, LAHF, SAHF, PREFETCH, FLDPI, FLDCW, FXSAVE, LEA and LDS.
elements.2211.03068_ca38bd88d6bf9dee5025cdd3957a2: : These instructions provide support for operating systems and include instructions LOCK, LGDT, SGDT, LTR, STR and XSAVE etc.
elements.2211.03068_046540ddcf062a2d229d575a8f044: : All other instructions that do not fit into any other group are included in this group of instructions, such as NOP, CPUID, SCAS, CLC, STC, CLI, HLT, WAIT, MFENCE, PACKSSWB, MAXPS, and UD (undefined instruction).
elements.2211.03068_442d30feb448dd0adfc340f2f7c6c: Designing a language that is small and simple, and accurately represent all these instructions for structural and behavioral information is non-trivial
elements.2211.03068_603084c22e6647b18945aa03c10cc: Our goal is to create as few statements as possible in the intermediate language and map as many instructions as possible to these statements
elements.2211.03068_e0f0704e6163774ea11c981645bd1: For example we do not translate (i.e: ignore) the following x86 instructions:
elements.2211.03068_e1b54f03e14c9df8e564065f307c5: The complete list of x86 and ARM instructions that are not translated into the MAIL statements is given in Appendix
elements.2211.03068_f4c7dff06be53f76b934fc584d1ce: Majority of the assembly instructions are data moving instructions, as shown above
elements.2211.03068_706a819f111edb64a00a7f5cf2ac9: In the following two MAIL assignment statements we cover the data transfer, arithmetic, logical and some of the system instructions
elements.2211.03068_1b56efe82367b3d363717a6f5d1b3: Control instructions are very important because they can change the behavior of a program, and they can be changed or added by polymorphic and metamorphic malwares to avoid detection
elements.2211.03068_160f6f8cccdfa5f4aef81f8ce9185: The following MAIL control statement represent the control instructions:
elements.2211.03068_9ad2c084a8ee591d4f8614b0c3b53: All the MAIL language statements can be divided into the following 8 basic statements
elements.2211.03068_66dec930b99e5f9b2aa8237eb83f1: The complete MAIL grammar is given in Appendix
elements.2211.03068_f5de05985befcaf86087350d342fc: Every statement in the MAIL language has a
elements.2211.03068_c3009b348844b4d205cc5016b8542: that can be used for pattern matching during malware analysis and detection
elements.2211.03068_e65a4545e9ecf56ec508b9100aac4: are introduced and explained in Section
elements.2211.03068_d496a3cb3378ddb4453c3abb1d8b3: MAIL has its own registers but also reuses the registers present in the architecture that is being translated to the MAIL language
elements.2211.03068_46671c1e395b57b2654802063c8a4: There are other special registers such as:
elements.2211.03068_1ce8d69a6d28ebee0244a97a06b35: ZF (zero flag), CF (crry flag), PF (parity flag), SF (sign flag) and OF (overflow falg)
elements.2211.03068_0c31734421485a4aeaec2ff797a55: These flag registers are of size one byte and are used in conditional statements. e.g: if (ZF == 1) jmp 405632;.
elements.2211.03068_2a83b9315e5dc334578d486031e9b: To keep track of the stack pointer.
elements.2211.03068_35c5b7f6911df5353bb1a464024b1: These are infinite number of general purpose registers for use in integer and floating point instructions respectively.
elements.2211.03068_cdc8fb9ce27b8b3f6aa83d5004cee: We have added 22 library functions to the MAIL language
elements.2211.03068_099f961508cd5251115229d91e12a: gives details about all these library functions
elements.2211.03068_00e46a689b11991ce6bec7a99e696: These library functions can help in translating most of the complex assembly instructions present in current processors architecture
elements.2211.03068_c5efe202d638fb35ece2c2c6c17bd: The purpose of these functions is not to capture the exact functionality of the assembly instruction(s) but to help in analysing the structure and the behavior of the assembly program, and capturing some of the patterns in the program that can help detect malwares.
elements.2211.03068_4f84a50cc65cd65f94cf5b3f802c5: MAIL language can also be used to annotate a CFG of a program using different patterns available in the MAIL language
elements.2211.03068_b5c45c5edbb9d697516329d6eba1d: The purpose of these annotations is to assign patterns to MAIL statements that can be used latter for pattern matching during malware detection
elements.2211.03068_0575bf928d8abb76c89b11e759330: gives an example of a CFG with pattern annotation and Section
elements.2211.03068_a1a80b98a07f10b6c35ef433dcf49: explains how they are used in malware detection
elements.2211.03068_eb76d772e3e5bbd5da36e02b1425b: More than one statements in the MAIL langauge can have one pattern
elements.2211.03068_9889b98012590fd9965de595d48e1: There are total 21 patterns in the MAIL language and are listed and explained as follows:
elements.2211.03068_9a487cd36bad82147b2c7aa04761f: An assignment statement including a constant.
elements.2211.03068_0bfefad5484831933ee20c438a8b2: A control statement where the target of the jump is unknown.
elements.2211.03068_0612980ce4ad5cb6d721393f85ce7: A control statement where the target of the jump is known.
elements.2211.03068_646ceadc59329623129e9c1b756f8: A call statement where the target of the call is unknown.
elements.2211.03068_58a8372e749d317451c1bbd12cfa0: A call statement where the target of the call is known.
elements.2211.03068_008abc50e02c00205d6d46f653fe5: A statement including flag register with stack.
elements.2211.03068_e8f4ee71582715346c46ec0ab2f88: A jump statement where the target of the jump is unknown.
elements.2211.03068_f8047130ca89c69eccef40b0f9cf1: A jump statement where the target of the jump is known.
elements.2211.03068_9f841062cc942020d8da14388b9d5: A library call including a constant.
elements.2211.03068_31eee21d189203b6692c9fad705f5: A stack statement including a constant.
elements.2211.03068_5b397bd7f64b189de213ec52174f0: A test statement including a constant.
elements.2211.03068_4e56d530d284af99197dab2e3c3d9: Any unknown assembly instruction that cannot be translated.
elements.2211.03068_fa6fd8d2c9460cf8c9f072cb16e83: All the new statements when created are assigned this default value.
elements.2211.03068_e786f58b41f386439cf2fa9da756c: For translating a binary program, we first disassemble the binary program into an assembly program
elements.2211.03068_fe984fa9fc0b5fe1a8a48269cdc51: Then we translate this assembly into MAIL program
elements.2211.03068_5e73e0cf5a9db5db0b483b5efaf50: We use a sample program, one of the malware samples, to give an example of the steps invlove in the translation as shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_752e429725a1eb010e11cfb795b43: This example shows how x86 assembly program is translated to MAIL program
elements.2211.03068_7af45fce52d148275765208ad4df8: we give an example of translating an ARM assembly program to MAIL program.
elements.2211.03068_fc1fef5f743f4530a93893da084c5: The binary analysis of the function shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_08331d381dc540eec6a705d37c9aa: have identified 5 blocks in this function labelled 18 - 25

elements.2211.03068_bb2ee3ab382860d1c1a66fb6a93a8: sets the direction flag in block 19
elements.2211.03068_f4dc170f0685c86d7e74cb6443f14: Each MAIL statement is associated with a
elements.2211.03068_58b574349b1421baa1b349fa2bda4: in the MAIL language as explained in Section
elements.2211.03068_46673ff1a23ca36c014b21e042ee8: For example an assignment statement with a constant value and an assignment statement without a constant value are two different
elements.2211.03068_8c2dfa3d2d5acfb2d3c2b4e251d4e: Jump statements can have upto three
elements.2211.03068_3f9d75f723af0a5e2265fc5a6e4a2: that are assigned during translation to the statements in block 21 shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_c6438723d202509972aa2d0815061: These patterns are used to annotate a CFG for pattern matching
elements.2211.03068_6a654dc0fe3a7320d971c7fd0e6b9: explains how they help and improve malware detection.
elements.2211.03068_d91b82bfbbe58ee9ab2451d908401: Translation of an ARM Program to MAIL Program
elements.2211.03068_9a692fa9097850ea274f121ac631d: In the previous Section we gave an example of translating x86 assembly program to MAIL program
elements.2211.03068_cca176797d903100facf171d723ff: As already mentioned that MAIL as a common language for different platforms, such as x86 and ARM binaries, helps malware analysis and detection tools to achieve platform independence
elements.2211.03068_d923c2566abb0c10de1eda7c58db6: In this Section we provide an example of translating an ARM assembly program to MAIL program
elements.2211.03068_a60e5df187baddb05041b471f9497: shows an example of such a translation.
elements.2211.03068_9dad6670158ee9506df201e19abaf: The main obvious difference in an ARM program and a x86 program is the length of the instructions as shown in Figures
elements.2211.03068_2abfffa7d83b12c2f9d9b355e5428: The size of the hex dump of each instruction of the x86 program is different
elements.2211.03068_97f93651f0abba8d08842eb8adfbd: Whereas the size of the hex dump of the ARM program is the same for each instruction
elements.2211.03068_80a9acf5cb9af4c789f4dc7d16091: For the sake of completeness we also show the CFG of this program in Figure
elements.2211.03068_5a16b2a120ffc978e6c7d9b4f39e2: the binary analysis have identified 10 blocks in the program
elements.2211.03068_f3744fdcabb27359d87ea12e89f7c: instructions are translated to assignment statements
elements.2211.03068_9bea3df15ddc870e55c18cb975e42: Branch instructions are translated to either simple
elements.2211.03068_59e5788491fd615b9330549b6961e: is translated using the MAIL library function
elements.2211.03068_b0432c3ceeb32db82a6a1c9a09a5f: shows the CFG of the sample program shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_7f77d5e756e35c9bb229f28ca71fe: The CFG clearly indicates two back edges and two forward edges that change the control flow of the program
elements.2211.03068_07262645e08a8079a3c716490031d: The fifth edge that jumps out of the function shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_4b9ecf86a52029470fd1528bdb211: is not shown in this CFG
elements.2211.03068_1595789ef4154bb260e7f6c60ac2c: There are two loops one outer loop
elements.2211.03068_3e3a61229acab87be69f705ebcee2: After the binary analysis performed above we get a CFG of a program as shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_01619ca597473999588d89ef8f1ba: For detecting if a program contains a malware we compare the CFG of a program with the CFG of a known malware
elements.2211.03068_2a7e8536ada2cf3373f3a3606b715: If the CFG of the malware matches the complete or part of the CFG of the program then the program contains a malware, i.e; the program is not benign
elements.2211.03068_f1d12a01ed675c1e35d8117bf66bc: We formulate this problem of malware detection as follows: Let
elements.2211.03068_1af54aaef9eb675a37c5f51576e13: is graph of the program and
elements.2211.03068_c78ff9aa3d19975510bded4169e51: is graph of the malware, where
elements.2211.03068_8f5278d2a2d254c38057394bb600b: are the vertices and edges of the graphs respectively
elements.2211.03068_bf788e766781e9f84a10db0b9963e: We solve this problem using subgraph isomorphism (matching)
elements.2211.03068_2a621e242fca4437d140d42b7815c: Given the input of two graphs it determines if one of the graphs contains a subgraph that is isomorphic (similar in shape) to the other graph
elements.2211.03068_0d1204db0c1b136a0c4be5cfec593: Generally subgraph isomorphism is an NP-Complete problem
elements.2211.03068_ca9fded954b9d37177ed2dbc476a1: A CFG of a program is a sparse graph therefore it is possible to compute the isomorphism of two CFGs in a reasonable amount of time
elements.2211.03068_3611545e3a9087df142cc03e6c0c9: Very small graphs when matched against a large graph can produce a false positive matching
elements.2211.03068_54ce9f38926fe8d81315c37c6680d: We conducted an experiment (more details in the next paragraph) and found that some of the malware samples after normalization were reduced to a small graph of 3 nodes as shown in Table
elements.2211.03068_301ffa039b7100f72f150acf5fdb3: and were responsible for producing a large number (87.85
elements.2211.03068_65e11fffdb23d7de10563e27332ca: To take care of these and other such graphs we also implemented a
elements.2211.03068_2b66d8c1c00978b820a975a789d32: Every statement in the language MAIL is assigned a
elements.2211.03068_e5a137515d8eaac1d88cae2a48f15: to match each statement in the matching nodes of the two graphs
elements.2211.03068_f79fd47977e9fa8f485a336e16df0: One of the CFGs of a malware sample, shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_9bfcdbb6199a07bf659f00e9e365f: to a subgraph of one of the CFGs of a benign program, shown in Figure
elements.2211.03068_6b89da4751637f135fdce8e906f94: Considering these two CFGs as a match for malware detection will produce a wrong result, a false positive
elements.2211.03068_ad7b8a147e1f29979ece9b302b4b4: The statements in the benign program do not match with the statements in the malware sample
elements.2211.03068_29a6bfe54b1c99b71a6867bbab49c: To reduce this false positive we have two options: (1) we can match each statement exactly with each other or (2) assign patterns to these statements for matching
elements.2211.03068_83164cf6148a28fed447f172fd350: Option (1) will not be able to detect unknown malware samples and is time consuming, so we use option (2) in our approach, which in addition to reducing false positives has the potential of detecting unknown malware samples.
elements.2211.03068_9983e0bc7d3211e286d1aa7371430: we require all the statements in the matching
elements.2211.03068_dcfd152a34301b307048e79f67b07: The statements in all the other blocks do not satisfy this requirement, therefore these CFGs fail the
elements.2211.03068_a6ebdff0dde287e3d4e418c35491f: To verfiy that by adding the
elements.2211.03068_de351b37a7d864094b31773f76788: component we have improved the metamorphic malware matching technique,
elements.2211.03068_5cc054fd68c135def2fdddda935c6: The dataset used for the experiment consisted of total 4289 samples, including 266 malware samples
elements.2211.03068_8d333a7c9dfe50a09ed5312295f50: Out of the 266 malware samples 250 were metamorphic malwares
elements.2211.03068_8f250cc3c7a42c82d3318f8ab2faf: Out of these 250 metamorphic malware samples we randomly selected 27 samples (10.11
elements.2211.03068_91741f49701f7c476d8ca00de87aa: of all the malware samples) for use in the experiment for matching
elements.2211.03068_aa30b8d49172118aacbdd79ef73e5: Dataset distribution based on the size of the CFG after normalization is shown in Table
elements.2211.03068_329584cc1473b4189b23f83363f15: The complexity (size) of these graphs range from 0 nodes to 63289 nodes
elements.2211.03068_1eaef1b544d5726a9f83db8881662: Some of the Windows DLLs (dynamic link libraries) that were used in the experiment do not have code but only data (cannot be executed) and that is why they have 0 node graphs (CFGs)
elements.2211.03068_66550ac47ddc7efb94146caeefb78: All the 4289 samples were matched against the 27 selected malware samples
elements.2211.03068_2bbb30deef5d83de755377e4d5c43: The results of this experiment are shown in Table
elements.2211.03068_79d04bc694a00618593dd6946c0b8: The reason for this large number of false positives, as explained earlier, is because of the small size (3 nodes as shown in Table
elements.2211.03068_b35aef7f40256bbd51a120d73a17a: This large false positive has been reduced to 0 when in addition to the
elements.2211.03068_a9ddff31e89afbf4e4c2ed17d8993: technique the number of graphs matched were not 27 but 168
elements.2211.03068_d7dac45860f0e74a5f100c16d9f9c: The 27 malware graph samples were not only matched with the same 27 graphs but they were also matched with additional 141 metamorphic malware graphs
elements.2211.03068_8e65cb03bb60e8a1bbceea52bf48b: When checked manually the nodes matched contained the same patterns as found in one of the 27 malware graph samples used for matching
elements.2211.03068_b28eb57aa4edd8661ce4b5e8c96e5: That means some of the unknown metamorphic malwares were also detected because of the use of the

elements.2211.03068_f840fe13c445dc04f370dfda9235a: Empirical Study of Using the MAIL Language
elements.2211.03068_6fd004a84fda6bba64747911a27ec: We carried out an empirical study to analyse the correctness and the efficiency of our techniques described above using the MAIL language
elements.2211.03068_e2b4b2b755ff6f55021f0a8bc22cd: This Section describes this empirical study
elements.2211.03068_8ba37bc27e4209485612ae60e38a8: We developed a prototype tool called MARD that uses MAIL for malware analysis and detection as described above
elements.2211.03068_acfd9cff2cc262d4cc2ed47c49e20: We collected different metamorphic malwares and Windows programs as samples to use in our tool.
elements.2211.03068_b38ff9fd2e61fa9977013fffdf3ab: Our dataset for the experiments consisted of 1387 programs
elements.2211.03068_e51183f45bcd2ca91899b385f47eb: Out of these: 250 are metamorphic malware samples collected from two different resources
elements.2211.03068_4ef705229d45b8328f225949b13bb: , and the other 1137 are Windows benign programs
elements.2211.03068_e4876c48aafbfe7b25a4b925f238e: gives more details about this dataset.
elements.2211.03068_2d7da976a89dd1938fd0ee2732958: The data set contains a variety of programs with simple CFGs to complex CFGs for testing
elements.2211.03068_a5f1f04e45776e2e706f1d7dea8af: As shown the size of the CFG of the malware samples range from 3 nodes to 129 nodes, and the size of the CFG of the benign programs range from 17 nodes to 15343 nodes
elements.2211.03068_6457991989b973e894563c5141e05: This variety in the samples provides a good testing platform for graph and pattern matching techniques used in our tool.
elements.2211.03068_59187fc60642953bde58c80388c49: Two experiments were carried out using our tool MARD to detect metamorphic malwares:
elements.2211.03068_140116e60f49e9fd1d99cfe805adc: In the first experiment we wanted to see if the tool can detect all the known malwares
elements.2211.03068_c962188f7f96aa06fcd24906414f9: This experiment consisted of 250 known malware samples in the test data set.
elements.2211.03068_391355c5067d55fc61529b5d39569: In the second experiment we wanted to see if the tool can detect the unknown malwares
elements.2211.03068_0a2e6d39f97ad2d2387d3f8484d77: This experiment consisted of 225 unknown malware samples in the test data set
elements.2211.03068_3de827b7cf9dbeab5ba7c19dcebc2: The results for this experiment were obtained using 10-fold cross validation
elements.2211.03068_4de057b94554e05c14575afa2c67f: This Section gives details about these experiments and the results obtained.
elements.2211.03068_b32b0b56fe53a39b3b181565fd08d: The tool MARD first builds the training dataset, also called
elements.2211.03068_8b8dff77c6c1302c683ac30729d2d: After a program (sample) is translated to MAIL and to a CFG the tool detects the presence of malwares in the program, using the
elements.2211.03068_e3ad72c7d880b2a76e995ac2e252c: and applying the graph and the pattern matching techniques described above
elements.2211.03068_4aea23766f95a8a9d064c299dcb8e: We ran the experiment on the two machines with 2 (using 8 threads) and 4 Cores (using 64 threads) listed in Table
elements.2211.03068_884e4852712057dc10e7db1ec948e: There was no manual intervention during the complete run
elements.2211.03068_5d2bc95543693b5a77e42647f5857: The tool automatically generated the report after all the samples were processed.
elements.2211.03068_36434ecf133429302b20b30434d07: For this experiment we selected 25 malware samples out of the 250 malwares
elements.2211.03068_fbc4c7b9745649bf0b62ee0b14f06: These 25 malware samples were used to train the tool MARD to classify a program as benign or malware
elements.2211.03068_c186801046412d594157434d5f6a6: These two steps were repeated 10 times and each time different set of 25 malware samples were selected for training (10-fold cross validation)
elements.2211.03068_f4a5d7b84caffb3ce4876ac8ceba2: After the program (sample) is translated to MAIL a CFG for each function in the program is build
elements.2211.03068_7ccf30119734c04ef87dcbea08101: Instead of using one large CFG as done in Experiment
elements.2211.03068_72c79f9eec8a0738f91ea7ea68426: , we divide a program into smaller CFGs
elements.2211.03068_6487a88e83193329a9853a514f16a: A program that contains some percenatge of the control flow of a training malware sample, can be classified as a malware
elements.2211.03068_b4bf4ddf54e1c3fe06a97c25525b4: The CFGs of a program help the tool MARD to detect such unknown malwares as explained below.
elements.2211.03068_c121badd54fdf800131b44882c931: Applying the graph and the pattern matching techniques described above the tool MARD matches CFGs of each 25 malware samples with the CFGs of a program to classify the program as either benign or malware
elements.2211.03068_d67bcdcea99f025ca2e7ced787a10: We base these classifications on a threashold value of 25
elements.2211.03068_8e603128f5ba1d3bf4b7f3de05d8d: or more of the CFGs of a malware sample matches with the CFGs of a program then the program is classified as malware, else the program is classified as benign
elements.2211.03068_9d5c7ca9ae2456d838c0bbf9b893b: The threshold value was computed by carrying out experiments with different range of threshold values as shown and explained in Table
elements.2211.03068_42f26ec057e617bfb673f7c82c8e2: because of the use of small number (25) of training dataset
elements.2211.03068_5182ad26a521235684bec64b13d52: when we used a training dataset of 100 and 200 samples respectively.
elements.2211.03068_f04fc4708d903f5b26324fbc74b75: A program translated to MAIL when executed may not produce the same output as the original program
elements.2211.03068_60aba9a182cd0f0c5be7f9e5f1cb2: The language MAIL is designed to perform static binary analysis and is not suitable for performing dynamic binary analysis
elements.2211.03068_a946fcd890de24f7f4c5f6d1ae436: The patterns developed if used with a behavioral signature of a binary program such as a CFG have the capability to produce useful classifications for malware analysis and detection, as shown by the results of the above experiments
elements.2211.03068_6671693b9db5b48616c40f93d73c9: But if the patterns are used alone, it may not produce the desired results
elements.2211.03068_aff78330d1217e89d647a25b4567c: The side effects of an assembly instruction is not directly translated to the MAIL statement
elements.2211.03068_1a4c2eb043fa4259d49c3f97c0970: With the presence of various flag registers in the MAIL language it is possible for a malware analysis tool to include the side effect(s) of an assembly instruction by generating more statements and updating the affected flag registers
elements.2211.03068_a9f51fb635f65594574bf5ef7f7d4: The MAIL language is most useful in capturing the behavior (including structural and functional) of a binary program and can be used as part of different malware detection techniques such as described in this paper and in
elements.2211.03068_403aac5be66f8b5e831b77c9c13c1: These techniques require behavioral, structural or functional information about a program
elements.2211.03068_7b2086de7aceb381e737580816864: In its current form the MAIL language cannot be used as part of other signature-based malware detection techniques, such as
elements.2211.03068_f8ca968120a1969f285feb35e1654: These techniques build the signatures using the opcodes of a binary program.
elements.2211.03068_1ac745874a062851ddec94b37d82b: We have developed the new language MAIL for malware anlaysis and have used it successfully in our tool MARD for malware analysis and detection
elements.2211.03068_4ede8d5c1b980a47e3ac07c5b146e: We carried out an experimental study and showed that we can achieve detection rates of: 100
elements.2211.03068_fb5718f2ea237b2f7af30337bca16: false positives for known malwares and
elements.2211.03068_ad7c564ad1c066be3b78208649049: false positives for unknown malwares, as shown in Table
elements.2211.03068_6d53dafcf1693e0a9303c8ca18187: The two main contributions of the language MAIL are:
elements.2211.03068_47dfcb05c852dd81db06555948ade: Providing platform independence and automation for malware analysis and detection tools, as is shown by its use in the tool MARD.
elements.2211.03068_e71eda2a448a5e54abcd76c96f2e4: Optimizing the creation of a behavioral signature of a program, as is shown by creating a ACFG (Annotated Control Flow Graph), a CFG with patterns, of a binary program
elements.2211.03068_e636cf3b7211385d2d3b2d4b19f66: We have shown how this ACFG is used for reliable malware analysis and detection in real-time
elements.2211.03068_7eb020d703c7aa6cab37cda14d571: More recent examples of the use of MAIL can be found in
elements.2211.03068_8c33dddc88d9e7e819f51012e7e68: Currently we are carrying out further research into optimizing the tool to increase its accuracy and efficiency for detecting unknown metamorphic malwares
elements.2211.03068_aed1e12117d78deeb4e78f8c811ff: We found that the behavioral signatures generated by the tool MARD using the MAIL language, and the graph and the pattern matching techniques, are helpful in detecting metamorphic malwares as shown in Table
elements.2211.03068_c795676c84130ba138039f48e945e: We are collecting more metamorphic malware samples to use in our research and carry out experiments to further improve malware classification and detection.
